items.title: Allow for getting the translator names of each language quickly
items.body:
I'm currently updating the credits of our own project and I find myself skimming through the list of .po files to find out who translated which file. 

It'd be nice if the tx client offered a way to get the list of translators for each language.

items.title: Asking for help to solve the dependency conflict issues of the transifex-client's downstream projects
items.body:
Hi, a similar issue as #271 ,  your downstream project money-to-prisoners-common suffered from a similar dependency conflict issue caused by the tight version constraint of package _**urllib3**_ set by **_transifex-client_**.

As shown in the following link [#issue 378](https://github.com/ministryofjustice/money-to-prisoners-common/issues/378).

Could you please loosen the version constraint of  _**urllib3**_, to remove this dependency hell?

Thanks for your help!

items.title: Asking for help to solve the dependency conflict issues of the transifex-client's downstream projects
items.body:
Hi, your downstream project **_money-to-prisoners-common_** suffered from a similar dependency conflict issue caused by the tight version constraint of package **_six_** set by **_transifex-client_**.

As shown in the following link [#issue 377](https://github.com/ministryofjustice/money-to-prisoners-common/issues/377).

Could you please loosen the version constraint of **_six_**, to remove this dependency hell?

 @diegobz  Thanks for your help!

items.title: Python API instead of CLI
items.body:
Currently we seems to only provide the CLI tool `tx`. Would be useful if Python API is provided. Example:

```python
import transifex

transifex.push(source=True, translations=True, language='en-US')
```

items.title: after updating tx to latest version i now get an error message "not found"
items.body:
I have been using this command:
`/usr/local/bin/tx -r /home/user/transifex pull -a --mode=reviewed`
to run `tx` for several years now and after i updated to 0.13.6 (today) i now get this error message:
`tx ERROR: Command /home/user/transifex not found`

Doesn't the `-r` working anymore or what is going on?

If i run `tx` from inside the same folder (in this case transifex) it seems to work but i need to use `-r` as i always have done.

items.title: Support for python 3.4
items.body: There are a lot of distros that ship with Python 3.4. We (Zulip) currently supports trusty-python-3.4, xenial-python-3.5 and bionic-python-3.6. Since you folks dont support Python 3.4 we have not been able to upgrade transifex-client in a while. Please consider adding support to Python 3.4

items.title: --version information written to stderr not stdout
items.body:
Version affected: v0.13.4 (may affect others, this is what I've tested)

Problem: When running `tx --version` the output from the command is written to the stderr.

Expected behaviour: Output from `tx --version` should be written to the stdout.

Steps to replicate:

```sh
$ tx --version > test.txt
0.13.4, py 2.7, x86_64
$ cat test.txt
```
```sh
$ tx --version 2> test.txt
$ cat test.txt
0.13.4, py 2.7, x86_64
```

When tooling wants to inspect the version of software installed it expects to be able to read from the stdout what the output is. As the output from `tx --version` is not error output it should not be written to the stderr.

items.title: tx pull issues "WARNING:  -> fr: fr.po" but no details on what it's actually warning about
items.body:
Running `tx pull -l fr -f` (force needed as described in #233), I get this output:
```
$ tx pull -l fr -f
tx INFO: Pulling translations for resource mageia.drakx_share (source: libDrakX.pot)
tx WARNING:  -> fr: fr.po
tx INFO: Done.
```

With debug:
```
$ tx -d pull -l fr -f
<snip>
tx DEBUG: Adding to new translations: set()
tx DEBUG: Pulling languages for: {'fr'}
tx INFO: Pulling translations for resource mageia.drakx_share (source: libDrakX.pot)
tx DEBUG: Using file fr.po
tx DEBUG: Downloading translation due to -f
tx WARNING:  -> fr: fr.po
tx INFO: Done.
```

This `WARNING:  -> fr: fr.po` is confusing, especially since it's not giving any details on what it's warning about. Is it meant to be an `INFO` level message?

It seems to be a recent change as I see this behaviour in 0.13.4 but it was different in 0.12.4:
```
Adding to new translations: set()
Pulling languages for: {'fr'}
Pulling translations for resource mageia.drakx_share (source: libDrakX.pot)
Using file fr.po
Downloading translation due to -f
 -> fr: fr.po
Done.
```

Apart from the `tx LEVEL:` the messages are the same, so I think the line explicating the remap is just wrongly set to `WARNING`.

items.title: Be able to skip prompt when pulling to avoid CI blocking (> v0.12.5)
items.body:
Hello,

I am Cedric, a developer from the Cozy Cloud front team. 
We use `transifex-client` via Travis to pull automatically all our applications locales during the CI using a Transifex token. And the last releases of the client added a new prompt when the authentication failed. 
When the token is provided, all work correctly.
My issue is when we want to build a project not configured yet with transifex or when we have pull requests from forks (Travis doesn't provide the encrypted token when it's from forks). In these cases the authentication failed because the token is missing. We used to have `tx pull -a || true` before to not breaking the build, but now the new prompt is clearly blocking the process and breaks the build after a timeout ([example](https://travis-ci.org/gcoter/cozy-music/builds/364055867#L746)).

Is it possible to have an option to skip this prompt and just log the failure error messages instead?
For now, the only one solution we have is to freeze our CI transifex-client to the 0.12.5 version :/

items.title: Need to bump version requirement of urllib3
items.body:
Currently there is no version specifier for urllib3 in the [requirements](https://github.com/transifex/transifex-client/blob/a706ba0cb910e66e852010bcd742221363c7e8be/requirements.txt#L1). However, since #196, transifex-client begins to [import module `urllib3.connection`](https://github.com/transifex/transifex-client/pull/196/files#diff-6a011c0e4d8087ddbdb9793f8fdfad48R7), which only presents after [urllib3 1.8 release](https://github.com/shazow/urllib3/compare/1.7.1...1.8). Missing the version requirement of urllib3 causes problem if the system has an old version of urllib3 installed, because it cannot be automatically updated by installing transifex-client.

----

I am wwylele from [citra](https://github.com/citra-emu/citra) project. We have just added `tx push` to our CI (the script is [here](https://github.com/citra-emu/citra/tree/master/.travis/transifex)). A month ago, when it was still under test, it worked without problem with transifex-client 0.12.5. However, today when it was merged into master branch (and the version is now 0.13.0), the CI failed on `tx push` with the following error:
```
+tx push -s
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/tx", line 11, in <module>
    load_entry_point('transifex-client==0.13.0', 'console_scripts', 'tx')()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 572, in load_entry_point
    return get_distribution(dist).load_entry_point(group, name)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2752, in load_entry_point
    return ep.load()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2405, in load
    return self.resolve()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2411, in resolve
    module = __import__(self.module_name, fromlist=['__name__'], level=0)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/txclib/cmdline.py", line 7, in <module>
    from txclib import utils
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/txclib/utils.py", line 31, in <module>
    from txclib.exceptions import (
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/txclib/exceptions.py", line 7, in <module>
    from urllib3.connection import ConnectionError
ImportError: No module named connection
```
I also checked the urllib3 version on Travis CI, and it turned out to be 1.7.1 (Just one version before meeting the requirement...). This should be able to fix by adding the version requirement of urllib3.

items.title: support Python 3.6

The upcoming releases of Ubuntu and Debian will not offer Python 3.5, and Python 2.7 is End-Of-Life quite soon.   Please support the current version of Python, 3.6.  I package transifex-client for both Debian and Ubuntu, and can't update it there until it supports Python 3.6.

* the upcoming Debian/buster release currently uses 3.6.4: https://packages.debian.org/buster/python3

items.title: v0.13.0: unexpected keyword argument 'version'
items.body:
Hello,

I am Cedric, a developer from the Cozy Cloud front team. 
We use `transifex-client` via Travis to pull automatically all our applications locales during the CI. And the last release of the client 0.13.0 seems to have something broken, at least in our usage.
(We use python 3.5 in our script.)

Here is the trace:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/.local/bin/tx", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/home/travis/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/txclib/cmdline.py", line 51, in main
    parser = tx_main_parser()
  File "/home/travis/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/txclib/parsers.py", line 24, in tx_main_parser
    version=version, description=description, add_help=False
TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'version'
```

This problem seems to be due to the [`ArgumentParser` object](https://docs.python.org/3/library/argparse.html#argumentparser-objects) which doesn't accept the `version` argument from here:
https://github.com/transifex/transifex-client/blob/master/txclib/parsers.py#L23-L24

items.title: Version 0.12.5 of 32bit execs causes plenty of positives on VirusTotal
items.body:
Is there something wrong with the 32bit executable of the software?
Both the one depending on Python 2.7 and Python 3.5 causes plenty of positives on virus total.
See the following for the one depending on 2.7: https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/4392943605152e6052fcc48789b61ae7bab385d1f3a87483c8bcacfd8cd511f5/analysis/1509736911/
and the following on the one depending on 3.5:
https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/39365030dad0397af2a112d2a1e6764b5cb875c22e68efd677d6b75ef7239847/analysis/

The 64bit versions seems to be okay with only 1 positive (which is highly likely to be a false positive).

items.title: Push command gives UnicodeDecodeError on iOS strings file
items.body:
When running version `0.12.1` and attempting to run:

``` sh
tx push -s
```

I get:

```
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf8' codec can't decode byte 0xff in position 164: invalid start byte

It's a standard iOS `Localizable.strings` file in UTF-16. Downgrading to `0.10` lets me successfully upload the file.

To install the older version:

pip install 'transifex-client>=0.10.0,<0.10.1'`
```

items.title: Non interactive options should be support a 'yes' override
items.body:
When I'm using tx client in Travis or other automatic CLI, I need it to skip prompting and assume 'yes'.  Many CLIs support this with a '-y' switch.

So I'm proposing something like:
tx init -y --user=$TX_USERNAME --pass=$TX_PASSWORD

items.title: Support Python versions 3.4 and 3.5
items.body:
All recent Python 3 versions should be supported better sooner than later.
## Background

The Python eco-system, and Unix-style operating system specifically, are now ready to move away from Python 2, finally, and make Python 3 the new default. This is expected to happen, for example, in Debian / Ubuntu in spring 2016.

Also, Python version 3.5 was released in September 2015, and is expected to be the default Python version on Ubuntu starting with the next LTS release (see [plans for version 16.04](https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python)).

Hence, it is imperative to support Python versions 3.4 and 3.5. -- At the moment only 3.3 is supported along with Python 2.6 and 2.7 according to the [latest package on PyPI](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/transifex-client). However, Python 3.4 was already the default Python 3 version on Ubuntu 14.04, that's 1.5 years ago.

items.title: type = PHP_ARRAY outputs files with syntax errors
items.body:
Expected: No matter what the translator enters in Transifex, the resulting output should be a valid string in PHP ([spec](https://github.com/php/php-langspec/blob/master/spec/19-grammar.md#string-literals), [manual](http://php.net/manual/en/language.types.string.php#language.types.string.syntax)).

Actual: `tx pull` output an invalid string ([line 6](https://github.com/Elgg/Elgg/blob/1.12/mod/embed/languages/it.php#L6)) in one of the files.

Note that the [source file](https://github.com/Elgg/Elgg/blob/1.12/mod/embed/languages/en.php#L6) uses single-quoted strings; perhaps the client expects all strings to be double-quoted? If so, the [documentation](http://docs.transifex.com/formats/php/) should specify that.

I don't know exactly what character(s) were entered into Transifex that caused the problem, as someone else fixed it. I suspect it was `\`.

items.title: Pull in reviewed mode returns empty strings for resx files
items.body:
According to the [docs](http://docs.transifex.com/formats/):

>  Currently, the available modes when using the Client or the API, are:
> -  reviewed, for files having only reviewed translations.
> -  translator, for files that are suitable for off-line translation of the resource.
> -  developer, for files that are suitable to be used by developers in their source code tree.
> 
> However, some file formats require to have the untranslated entries filled in with the source strings so using one of the modes mentioned above you'll get a file that won't have the untranslated strings empty. For that case we also provide two modes that "bypass" this rule for the sake of conveniece. These modes are available when using the API.
> -  onlytranslated the response will include the translated strings and the untranslated ones will be returned empty.
> -  onlyreviewed, the response will include the reviewed strings and the rest (translated or not) will be returned empty.

So, as far as I can understand, `tx pull --mode=reviewed` should return only reviewed strings, but no others:

``` XML
...
<data name="//Host//HostSettings.String" xml:space="preserve">
    <value>Настройки хоста</value>
  </data>
...
```

But instead it returns empty strings for untranslated (and unreviewed):

``` XML
...
<data name="//Host//HostSettings.String" xml:space="preserve">
    <value>Настройки хоста</value>
  </data>
<data name="//Host//SiteManagement.String" xml:space="preserve">
    <value></value>
</data>
...
```

It looks like it works in _onlyreviewed_ mode (which, as docs state, available only via API).

This broke localization in case of some .NET apps (like DNN Platform), as app cannot fallback to a string in the default resource file if there is an empty string in the translation file.

items.title: Define trusted SSL certificate through transifex-client
items.body:
Currently, transifex-client inherits its SSL trust from the system's trust store. 

This means that the system the client is running on must globally trust the root that Transifex uses. Being able to define a trusted certificate directly with transifex-client would allow the certificate to only be trusted for transifex-client usage.

items.title: Underscore vs. hyphen in locale code
items.body:
By default underscores are used in locale codes, e.g "en_US"

For some applications hyphens might be preferred though, e.g. Firefox uses BCP 47 language codes that look like "en-US".

Therefore if you try to push or pull translations you'll inevitably end up with conflicts, e.g.
- American English translations ending up in a "en_US" folder when you'd expect an "en-US" folder.
- `pull -l en-US` failing (or rather succeding but doing nothing) because of the hyphen
- `push -t -l en_US` failing when your traslation is actually located in "en-US"

A possibility to define whether to use underscores or hyphens would be necessary (e.g. as command line option and/or config setting.
Otherwise an automatic detection would be required.

Note that the same considerations also apply regarding the case of the country code (e.g. "en_us" vs "en_US")

items.title: Wrong <lang> when resource is region specific
items.body:
It would be nice if transifex api would provide the correct region name in `<lang>` placeholder for android.

```
[android.strings]
source_lang = en
source_file = src/main/res/values/strings.xml
file_filter = src/main/res/values-<lang>/strings.xml
type = ANDROID
```

according to: http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/resources/providing-resources.html#AlternativeResources

The proper path for string resources would be: `values-[locale]-r[region]`
Which makes it reasonable for `<lang>` to be replaced by `[locale]-r[region]`. But this is not the case and it actually is: `[locale]_[region]` which is useless for android.

items.title: transifex-client: insufficient CVE-2013-2073 fix
items.body:
Commit e24ea95 (plus few follow up commits) was added to add verification of HTTPS certificate to avoid MITM attacks.  The issue got CVE-2013-2073 assigned.

However, the fix is not really correct. The way it works is:
- verify_ssl opens connection to the target host and verifies provided certificate, including name check
- connection opened by verify_ssl is closed immediately
- actual communication with the server is done via urllib2, which opens its own connection(s)

So the actual data is sent over unverified connections opened by urllib2.  MITM attacker should be able to steal all transferred data by allowing "probe" connection opened by verify_ssl to connect to the real transifex server and only intercept subsequent urllib2 connection.

items.title: AndroidFileFormat: line ending (termination) differs between template & translation > \n instead of  \r\n on windows systems
items.body:
This is a sequel to https://github.com/transifex/transifex/issues/123 , but unfortunetely I am not able to post a comment to the issue there and the issue itself is also more related to the transifex-client than transifex itself.

For introduction please read https://github.com/transifex/transifex/issues/123

This is still an issue. We are working around it by applying a "fix" script to the language files after pulling the translations, nevertheless it would simplify the transifex preparation process for new plugin repositories created by our community plugin developers and also simplify the build scripts of the existing repositories.

\r\n should be used by default on windows files systems instead of \n only or maybe have it available as a commandline switch.

items.title: RFE: ability to export a project's translations
items.body:
Can Transifex be enhanced with a feature that allows translations for a project to be exported, or saved all at once?

The use case is that, ideally, Red Hat would be able to re-use Fedora translations for RHEL documentation. Because Red Hat uses Zanata, this can currently only be done if both projects are on Zanata. If Transifex offered this functionality, cross-platform work will become possible.

items.title: Projects with large numbers of file and long filenames cannot be pushed or pulled
items.body:
I maintain the Fedora Installation Guide and Installation Quick Start Guide, and last year we had to move translation to another platform because of insurmountable difficulties with Transifex.

There are two problems:

1) Transifex can't seem to handle the long filenames that the sheer size of the Installation Guide necessitates, so we would have to maintain some kind of mapping between the filename and the Transifex module names. This would require a massive amount of manual handling.

One example of a long filename in the guide: Specialized_Storage_Devices_common-variablelist-1.xml

2) Pushing and pulling the 800+ small files that comprise the Installation Guide across the 20+ languages that we have partial translations for is prohibitive as the connection keeps failing. Only 368 files are currently in the Transifex project.

https://fedora.transifex.com/projects/p/fedora-install-guide/

Can the limitations on filename length and the number of files be extended so that Transifex can accept a project of this size?

items.body: Some projects prefer to not include e-mail addresses in their translation files for various reasons. Being able to simply use a command line switch/option to `tx pull`, or perhaps even a setting in the configuration, would make this process a lot smoother than having to postprocess the translation files after having been pulled.
